The 1919 football season at Hopkins was the most successful for a
number of years. Altogether the
team won four games, lost four
and tied one. The state championshop honors were again carried off
by Maryland State, which was
represented by one of the strongest
teams ever turned out at that institution. St. John's was tied in
one of the closest games staged between_ the two colleges for a number of years. The new coaching
system, in full effect for the first
time, proved to be a success, the
full measure of which cannot be
felt for a number of years. The
schedule was hard, and it was not
possible to have the hours for collegiate duties so arranged that the
team could get all the real practice it should have had. It is to
be hoped that in the future laboratories and afternoon classes can be
so arranged that the team will be
able to get in at least two hours of
real practice each day. This has
hen done in Harvard, Yale and
others of the large colleges. Students and faculty should be willing and glad to go out of their way
to promote better athletics at Hopkins.
In the first game of the year Mt.
St. Mary's was met and defeated,
13 to 6. The team had been on the
field only a week or so, and a lack
of training was very evident. The
up-staters were light but fast, and
while in no danger of losing at
any time, Hopkins was forced to
display its best to win. It became
evident that the team was especially in need of an experienced
center to make a good showing.
Cashell had been moved from his
old position at fullback into that
place, but his passing was badly
off color. The backfield displayed
plenty of punch, but it was very
evident that it needed practice in
order to work together.
On the following 'Saturday the
Navy was met at Annapolis, and,
as every one expected, Hopkins
was badly beaten, but anything
but disgraced, the Midshipmen
walking off with the lona end of a
66-to-0 score. In the ''first half
-Coach Murphy, who did not wish
to take any chances with his firststring men, sent in the second and
third teams, and the Navy managed to roll up 48 points. Many
people expected to see the score
mount up over the century mark
in the next two periods: Navy had
orders to run up the score as high

Last week the Black and Blue
basketeers felt both the testing of
defeat and the satisfaction of victory, the former at the hands of
the Navy and the latter from Galla ii(let.
The fast Academy five proved to
be too much for the local boys on
Wednesday at Dahlgreen Hall,
coming out at the end of the encounter with the fat half of a 3720 count. Fouling was heavy
throughout the game, 34 free
shots being called on the two
teams.
The first half was a nip-and-tuck
affair. First the Midshipmen and
then Hopkins would takes the lead.
Good, snappy teamwork on both
sides predominated, but the
marksmanship was below par.
Several times Hopkins had chances
to score easy goals, but hasty
shooting spoiled their aim. Long
shots on the part of Weiner and
Cuneo cropped out again, but
without suaess. Byerle was the
star performer for the Annapolitans, seeming to be able to find the
basket from any angle, dropping
in two goals by tossing the leather
over his shoulders. At another
time, after Watters had missed a
foul, Ile jumped up, tapping the
ball back into the basket as it fell.
Navy started off with a jump,
forcing Hopkins to assume the defensive. After a few minutes'
passwork, during which the Hopkins defense seemed impregnable,
Byerle at last broke through qnd
scored the first goal. Cuneo netted a foul, and then clever team
work on the part of Weiner and
Cuneo enabled the latter to score,
and Hopkins was ahead. Byerle
again turned the tables by netting
a long shot. The score see-sawed
back and forth, till just before the
whistle Navy took a spurt and the
half ended 15-11 in the favor of
the home team.
At the beginning of the second
period Weiner netted two goals in
rapid succession, tieing the count.
However, this seemed to be the
limit of the efforts of the Black
and Blue, for during the remainder of the contest only one more
basket was netted, while the future admirals piled up the score.

at Washington. The game was a
battle from the whistle. The end
of the first half found the mutes
with a lead of 1 point; but in the

The Johns Hopkins University ,
announceS in the. division of the
College Courses for Teachers a
course on American :art to be
given by Professor David M. Robinson, February 12 to May 27,
1920. This will be a study, illustrated by slides and photographs,
of the different phases of the development of art in America, and
will deal especially with architecture, sculpture and painting from
Colonial times down to and including contemporary art movements.

Roman revival. Latrobe, the introducer of Greek forms. The later
classicists. Domestic architecture. The
Gothic revival. Eclecticism. The adoption of Romanesque and Renaissance
forms. Neoclassicism and other modern forms. The Woolwoyth Building.

FEB. 3, 1920

Rah! for Mr. Kistler.

We do not believe that our undergraduate body quite realizes
just to what degree it is indebted
to Mr. Theodore Kistler for his labors, past and present, in our behalf. He has not only brought the
basketball team forth from its
semi-obscurity, but has filled a
long-felt need for something of a
social nature, not quite as elaborate as the cotillions and a little
more intimate than the pure-andsimple athletic contests. We are
offered each year, of course occasional Dramatic Club exhibitioiis, Glee Club concerts and varsity and inter-class debates, but
these do little more than begin to
fill the gap.
Our memories hearken back to
the old It 0. T. C. days of two
years ago, when Mr. Kistler performed for us a similar service in
organizing the popular series of
battalion hops. These were very
simply arranged, and were unanimously acclaimed successful in
every way. Last year we had our
S. A. T. C. hops and one or two
informal "Black and Blue" dances.
This year's social season will certainly surpass those which for several years have preceded it.
There but remains the mention
of a few of the ways in which we
may co-operate with Mr. Kistler,
Coach Murphy and the floor cornittee in bringing the basketball
dance series to its highest point of
success. Those who are not dancing should bear in mind the hints
of Mr. Murphy about smoking and
hats and blocking the floor. Those
whose tastes run to the more vibratory styles of dancing mightre-

term me the hydrogen in concentration ; beam-trawl hauls are taken
at the bottom in order to obtain
specimens of the larger animals
and plants found there.
The purpose of this survey is,
first, to determine the normal biological and physical conditions
throughout the year so that when
great mortality of fishes, oysters,
clams, crabs, etc. occur, there will
be normal data at hand from
which to determine the abnormal
conditions that bring about the
trouble; second, to learn all that
is possible concerning the movements of layers of water of different density, different temperature and different plankton content (fish food value), in the hope
that the information may throw
light on the migration of fishes
and crabs into and in Chesapeake
Bay at certain times of the year;
third, to study especially the fauna of deep holes which occur in
many places; fourth, to study the
so-called "barren bottoms" at the
mouths of rivers; fifth, to obtain
information of value to geologists
concerning the deposition of calcium carbonate by a study of the
hydrogen ion concentration, and
sixth, to gather as much information as possible which will bear on
the conservation of the fisheries
resources of Chesapeake Bay.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

A glance at the notices on the official bulletin board will convince
one that there are at Johns Hopkins a small number of "witty"
students who indulge in the petty
practice of adding finishing
touches to the spelling of many
words on the notices. This "leadpencil vandalism" should not be
tolerated here, and I, as one who
fails to be tickled by such humor,
urge that sophomore paddles be
used unsparingly upon these delinquents, regardless of their class
or age. The golden rule or paddle
should not be spared to abolish
this primary school habit that a
few boys still possess. Yours for
SENIOR.
decency,
Advocates Literary Magazine.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—It seems to me that Hopkins is somewhat deficient in the
number of its student publications. Most colleges of this size
support at least two, and often
three, undergraduate periodicals.
Hopkins has but one—THE NEWS
LETTER.

Certainly there should be established here a student literary
magazine. The argument that a
publication of this sort would not
be supported by male students
has little force in view • of the
notable success of the Princeton,
Yale and many other college litmagazines.
Especially
erary
since the organization of a University Literary Club does the
publication of a magazine seem
feasible, for by the success of this
club is shown that contributors
would not be lacking. The existence of a student literary periodical would, moreover, rouse the
members of the English composition classes to more conscientious exertion; readable and interesting essays and stories would
become far more abundant in
those masses of manuscript which
are weekly inflicted upon the English composition instructors, if
the authors of these contributions but had the incentive of seeing their articles appear in print.
And if the stories printed in this
magazine were respectably interesting and the essays moderately
entertaining there is no doubt

friends in their time of trial, theoretically speaking.
That's one thing I admire in
Dr. Dansig, his liberal ideas. The
other morning I heard him say:
"Mr. Harden, I don't mind you
being absent, I never count absences but I can't stand dumbness.'
You ought to get on to this
stuff, Mr. Harden, for some day
you'll be a math teacher. I predict, sir that you will fail in business, and
' fail in engineering, and
fail in the practice of the law, and
then you will become a math
teacher." "Speaking from your
own experience, Doctor?" said Mr.
Harden, and right there the argument ended.
From all that I can gather, Senor Cabello's class in Spanish elements takes the cake, wins the
grand pittno and in general walks
off with all the prizes when it
comes to furnishing material for
my illustrious quack column.
About a quarter of an hour before
the end of the period, Elmer Jones
breezed into the room last Tuesday morning amid uproarious
cheers and bursting peals of laughter. "That's all right, Mr. Jones,"
said the Senor, "that's a lot better
than loafing down at the postofUe and you know the Bible
says'
that the last shall be first."
And then after things had quieted
down a bit, Mr. Cabello asked,
"What is the present of the verb
%ober'?" "Albeit; what is it?"
answered wee "Billie" Hoffman.
I leave it to you, gentlemen, if
that class isn't a pig's knuckle.
Am I right, or am I right?
From the far and distant region of the Medical School comes
the faintly revibrating echo of the
new motto that the faculty is
preaching this year: "Keep 'em
alive, boys; keep 'em alive—dead
men pay no bills."
And that reminds me of a story
I have had in the back of my head
for a good many months. Dr.
"Hygiene" Abercrombie was giving our little red-headed "Dick"
Tome- his physical examination.
He seemed fit as a fiddle in every
way except one. "Doc" Abercrombie diagnosed, "You're a little
stiff." Quickly the Irish blood
came to the fore as "Dick" shot
back: "And you're a big stiff."
I wish you all kinds of luck on
your exams, gentlemen. I know
you hate 'em, but just think how
hard they fall on us faculty and
be consoled.

LECTRICITY has leveled

1-4 the Continental Divide. The

steam locomotive, marvelous as it is
after a century of development, cannot meet all of the presentdemandsfor
transportation facilities. Its electric
rival has proved to be far superior.

Some Advantages of
Railroad Electrification

On the mountain divisions of the
Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul
Railway—the world's greatest electrification—giant electric locomotives
today lift an ever increasing freight
tonnage over the mile-high Rockies
and also make traveling clean and
comfortable. They utilize the abundant energy of distant waterfalls and
then, by returning some of this
power to the trolley, safely brake the
trains on descending grades. And
their capabilities are not impaired
by excessively cold weather when the
Steam engine is frozen and helpless.

Saving the Nation's coal
Lower maintenance costs.
Greater reliability and fewer
delays.
Ability to haul smoothly
heavier trains at higher
speed.
Operation of electric locomotives unaffected by extreme
cold.
Ability to brake trains on
descending grades by returning power to the trolley.

ii

Electricity is the power which
drives the trains of New York City's
subway and elevated systems. It
operates the locks and tows the ships
through the Panama Canal. It propels the Navy's latest super-dreadnaught, the New Mexico. Electric
mine locomotives have replaced the
slow-moving mule and the electric
automobile has also come to doan important service. Such achievements
were made possible by the extensive
research and manufacturing activities
of the General Electric Company.
Electricity has become the universal
motive power. It has contributed
efficiency and comfort to every form
of transportation service and in this
evolution General Electric apparatus
has played a large part — from
mighty electric locomotives to
the tiny lamp for the automobile.

The Jaraary meeting of the
Johns Hopkins Zionist Society
took place on January 28, the
speaker being Mr. Abraham Caplan of the Jewish Big Brother
League of this city. Mr. Caplan
presented a very.thoughtful paper,
entitled "The Zionist and Jewish
Social Problems," in which he asserted that the Zionist should attempt to understand intelligently
the problems confronting the Jews
living in the modern countries of
today. Mere philanthropy is not
sufficient; the remedy lies in the
resumption of the more vigirous
Jewishness that characterized the
life of Jews in previous years.
To quote the speaker:
"Zionists can ill-afford to be
thoughtless in the matter of social
service. They cannot regard Jewish social problems from a standpoint other than Zionistic. The
Zionist, essentially a realist, must
realize that these problems will be
solved by a general return to the
Jewish manner of life rather than
by the formulae of social workers.
"The student of Jewish history
finds little solace in the large institution of philanthropy. As a
Zionist I object to the process of
pauperization which has come as
a result of the free expansion of
the philanthropic idea. * * *
"What should be the attitude of
the thoughtful Zionist with reference to Jewish social problems?
It should be cautious, rational
and intelligent. It should be that
of one who knows that Jewish
problems have causes and that the
causes are deserving of intenser
consideration that the conditions
themselves."
The reading of the paper was
• followed by a discussion by Dr.
Blondheim.
An announcement was made regarding dues. All members of the
Society who have not already done
so may enroll as members of the
Zionist Organization of America
by remitting two dollars ($2.00)
to Mr. A. Fedder, the treasurer of
the Society.
Attention is again called to the
Study Circle in - General Zionism.
This circle, which has so far
Proved quite popular, will resume
its weekly meetings after the examination recess on Friday, February 13, and vill contirnie to

If the present outlook may be
i.iken as a criterion, this should be
a banner lacrosse year for Hopkins from every standpoint. The
team N'ill undoubtedly live up to
the past Hopkins standard, as
nearly every member of last year's
team will be back and because
"Father Bill" Smeisser and
Rainey Wolfe will again be the
coaches.
The schedule is a hard one, for
the best lacrosse teams in the
rountry have been booked. In addition to the teams usually met,
the manager has gotten games
with Cornell, Harvard and Stevens, and is now negotiating with
Yale and Syracuse for matches.
Not only is the schedule a good
one, but it also has another great
advantage—probably every one of
the ten games except that with
Harvard will be played at home.
, In addition to the scheduled
games, if the Johns Hopkins team
wins the championship of the
Southern division of colleges, as
seems very probable, it will play
the champion of the Northern division early in June.
On Wednesday, January 14,
equipment was given out, and the
following day the first regular
practice was held under the direction of Captain "Ferdie"
Meyer. Since then practice has
been held every day the weather
has permitted, and every Wednesday and Saturday, rain or shine.
The coaches will be out on these
two (lays every week, and will give
blackboard talks if the weather is
too bad for practice.
Over sixty men have reported,
and about thirty more are expected after the examinations, when
practice will be begun in earnest.
Among these are the nine or ten
letter men and about as many
more from last year's Red Eagles.
It may well be seen that from
these and the new men who have
shown promise a team will be
picked which will uphold the Hopkins lacrosse reputation. The succes.s of lacrosse this year depends
on the team, the schedule and the
support. As the calibre of th_e
first two of these is assured, all
that is needed is the backing of
the student body.

A biological and hydrographic
survey of the waters of Chesapeake Bay is_being undertaken by
the Bureau of Fisheries under the
direction of Dr. R. P. Cowles, Associate Professor of Zoology in
Johns Hopkins University. In this
investigation all information possible is obtained concerning the
biological and physical conditions
that exist in Chesapeake Bay during spring, summer, fall and winter, and it is planned to continue
the work for several years. The
Fish Commission S. S. Fishhawk,
which is at the disposal of the
survey, makes six or seven cruises
at intervals during the year, and'
visits during each cruise some
thirty or forty stations distributed
in lines extending across the bay in
such a way as to cover all regions
of interest from Cape Charles and
Cape Henry to Swan Point and
North Point. At each station
quantitative samples of sea water
for salinity and plankton examination are taken at different
depths from the surface to the bottom, using the Green-Bigelow water bottle; horizontal and vertical
tow nets are employed to obtain
qualitative samples of the plankton, which are used to aid in the
study of the quantitative plankton
samples; accurate temperature
readings at the surface and at different depths are made by means
of reversing thermometers; the direction and velocity of the current
is determined at various depths by
means of the Eckman current

PROF. LOVEJOY ON TEACHING
Head of Department of Philosophy Addresses Freshmen on the Calling of
the University Teacher.

EIOR real enjoyment
and delight, one box
of Murads is worth a
dozen packages of
ordinary cigarettes that
"merely smoke.”

The first of a series of talks to
the freshman class on the vocations to which college students
look forward was given on Wednesday, January 2$, by Professor
Arthur 0. Lo.vejoy. As President
of the American Association of
University Professors, Dr. Lovejoy is eminently qualified to discuss the teaching profession. Of
the university teacher Ile said that
it should be clearly understood
that a man who is fitted to enter
this calling could earn more
money in another. If his future
happines depends upon his owning a motor car, and he cannot be
satisfied with the admirable contrivance of Mr. Henry Ford, he
should hesitate about becoming a
teacher. But there are other rewards for the teacher. • He has
what most men love, namely,
power. This is not power to boss
numbers of men or to direct human action, but power over civilization, influence upon the facts of
fundamental significance in the
life of man. From this point of
view the most powerful man of the
nineteenth century was Charles
Darwin.
Another intrinsic reward for
the university teacher is found in
life in a university community.
Next to the church, the university
is the most venerable and dignified
of associations, and most men
value the opportunity to do their
life's work under the conditions
which if offers.
A third recompense for the
scholar's labor is the fact that he
is in good company—the best of
the deads, in books, and successive generations of young men. By
these latter he is kept young and
made to look to the future rather
than to the past. His function as
a teacher enables him to influence
powerfully the leaders of the next
generation. Meanwhile he enjoys
the exercise of his own powers,
and if he has chosen wisely, is repaid by the fun of his job.

RESUME OF FOOTBALL SEASON

(Continuedfrom page I)
as possible, but the best they could
do against the first string, which
was put back in for the second
half, was to score 18 points. Hopkins made several good gains, getting three first downs in all; but
whenever the team was within
striking distance of the Navy goal
line a bad pass from the center
spoiled what looked several times
like a touchdown. Captain Jones
was injured in this game and did
not regain his old-time form until
the game with Western Maryland. Cashell was shifted back to
his old position at full for a part
of the game, and Cromwell was
given a chance to show what he
could do in center. His passing
was no better than that displayed
by Cashell a week before against
Mt. St. Mary's, and all loyal rooters were delighted to learn that
"Stem" Hecht, for two years AllMary land center, would return to
the iiversity.
A week of good hard practice
followed, and in the third game of
the season the fast Gallaudet
eleven was defeated, 33 to 9, Hopkins coming from behind in the
last quarter and scoring 27 points.
This game was very encouraging
to all Hopkins supporters, and it
was seen that the team was going
to have to be seriously considered
in the state championship race. A
real punch was uncovered in this
game, and the work of Cashell,
who returned to center, was all
that could be desired. In the
backfield the work of Hoffman was
especially good, while Tome, Bardiet and Watson left nothing to be
desired. Jones played a beautiful
game until he was knocked out in
the second quarter. The team had
now begun to show what it was
really capable of, and visions of
the state championship began to
appear in the distance.
The next week the team journeyed to Swarthmore, where it
met defeat at the hands of the fast
eleven representing that institution by a 20-to-6 score. The game
was played under the worst possible circumstances for the Hopkins eleven. The field was very
heavy and the backs were unable
to get foothold enough to start,
many plays hardly reaching the
line of scrimmage before they were
stopped by the Swarthmore men,
who were evidently used to playing on a field covered with three
inches of mud. Hecht played most
of the game at center, Cashell going back to his old position in the
backfield. Hampered and seemingly rather discouraged by the
mud, Hopkins failed to show
either the team-work or the driVe
that had characterized the play
against Gallaudet the week previous. Swarthmore had a fast,
heavy team, and every play was
covered in perfect interference.
• Hopkins' one score came after a

pretty run of 65 yards by Barchet,
who had intercepted a forward
pass.
Several changes were made for
the next gaine—that with Lebanon
Valley. Cashel' was again shifted
to center, and Calkins, who had
been end and general utility man,
was shifted to fullback. Hopkins
again showed a driving attack,
with Calkins as the chief ground
gainer. The game ended with
Hopkins a 20-to-6 victor. The work
of the line was especially good in
this game, the plunging attack of
Lebanon Valley being stopped by
the excellent work of Ed Wood,
Landy and Egerton. Particularly
pleasing to Hopkins was the unexpected ability displayed by Calkins, playing his first game in the
backfield.
Hopkins seemed rather overconfident, and the next week was defeated, 7 to 0, by Haverford in a
close and exciting game. Hopkins
should have been victor with comparative ease, but poor judgment
on the part of the quarterback and
the inexperience of Calkins, who
was stuck in long enough to permit Haverford to put a forward
pass over his head, proved a big
enough handicap to defeat the
Black and Blue. Hopkins showed
a powerful attack, but were unable to sustain it inside the 20yard line. Calkins was again the
best bet in the Hopkins attack,
and Landy did excellent work in
the line.
After d week of unusually hard
practice Western Maryland was
met in the first of the three state
games. The visitors were light and
absolutely unable to stop Hopkins' hard-charging backs. Captain
Jones showed a welcome return to
form in this game, running 70
yards for a touchdown on a play
inside tackle. The whole Hopkins
team performed creditably, both
the offense and the defense doing
their full share, the final count
being 30 to 6. Western Maryland
managed to get one touchdown on
a beautiful forward pass to their
veteran captain, Langrall. The
game was won without opening up
any of the new plays being saved
for the games with St. Johns and
State.
The next team on the schedule
was St. John's, and in this game
Hopkins seemed to be suffering a
bit from overconfidence, being
forced to the limit to hold the Soldiers to a 13-to-13 tie. Any one
who saw the games with Western
Maryland and State knows how
much Hopkins was off.form on
that day. Calkins and Jones
starred on the offense and on the
defense the tackling of Jones was
of the highest order. "Bill" Wood

Organized Measures Taken to Guard
Against Fire and Accident—Committees Appointed By President Goodnow.

President Frank J. Goodnow
has inaugurated a movement to
insure the maintenance and preservation of the splendid buildings
on the Homewood site by means of
building inspection committees, to
consist of the following members:
Gilman Hall—Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, Chairman; George Wagner,
Paul Hinrichs, Charles T. Leber,
George Deickman and Millard
Foard.
Mechanical
and
Electrical
Building—J. C. Smallwood, Chairman; Edel, H. H. Holland, Wessels and Salter.
Civil Engineering tuilding—W.
E. Dehoff, Chairman; Phillipy,
Herring, Zeskind and T. T. Hubbard.
Each committee has been instructed to make monthly inspections of their building and to report to President Goodnow regarding conditions found, particularly in regard to (a) fire risks,
(b) protection of equipment and
(c) careless practices.
Such efficient and reliable inspection will have a great influence on the morale of the University and also on the economic life
of the city, for it is hoped that the
student body will carry the same
ideas of safety into their later vocations. Further details regarding the movement will be given in
a later issue.

The 1919 football season at Hopkins was the most successful for a
number of years. Altogether the
team won four games, lost four
and tied one. The state championshop honors were again carried off
by Maryland State, which was
represented by one of the strongest
teams ever turned out at that institution. St. John's was tied in
one of the closest games staged between_ the two colleges for a number of years. The new coaching
system, in full effect for the first
time, proved to be a success, the
full measure of which cannot be
felt for a number of years. The
schedule was hard, and it was not
possible to have the hours for collegiate duties so arranged that the
team could get all the real practice it should have had. It is to
be hoped that in the future laboratories and afternoon classes can be
so arranged that the team will be
able to get in at least two hours of
real practice each day. This has
hen done in Harvard, Yale and
others of the large colleges. Students and faculty should be willing and glad to go out of their way
to promote better athletics at Hopkins.
In the first game of the year Mt.
St. Mary's was met and defeated,
13 to 6. The team had been on the
field only a week or so, and a lack
of training was very evident. The
up-staters were light but fast, and
while in no danger of losing at
any time, Hopkins was forced to
display its best to win. It became
evident that the team was especially in need of an experienced
center to make a good showing.
Cashell had been moved from his
old position at fullback into that
place, but his passing was badly
off color. The backfield displayed
plenty of punch, but it was very
evident that it needed practice in
order to work together.
On the following 'Saturday the
Navy was met at Annapolis, and,
as every one expected, Hopkins
was badly beaten, but anything
but disgraced, the Midshipmen
walking off with the lona end of a
66-to-0 score. In the ''first half
-Coach Murphy, who did not wish
to take any chances with his firststring men, sent in the second and
third teams, and the Navy managed to roll up 48 points. Many
people expected to see the score
mount up over the century mark
in the next two periods: Navy had
orders to run up the score as high

Last week the Black and Blue
basketeers felt both the testing of
defeat and the satisfaction of victory, the former at the hands of
the Navy and the latter from Galla ii(let.
The fast Academy five proved to
be too much for the local boys on
Wednesday at Dahlgreen Hall,
coming out at the end of the encounter with the fat half of a 3720 count. Fouling was heavy
throughout the game, 34 free
shots being called on the two
teams.
The first half was a nip-and-tuck
affair. First the Midshipmen and
then Hopkins would takes the lead.
Good, snappy teamwork on both
sides predominated, but the
marksmanship was below par.
Several times Hopkins had chances
to score easy goals, but hasty
shooting spoiled their aim. Long
shots on the part of Weiner and
Cuneo cropped out again, but
without suaess. Byerle was the
star performer for the Annapolitans, seeming to be able to find the
basket from any angle, dropping
in two goals by tossing the leather
over his shoulders. At another
time, after Watters had missed a
foul, Ile jumped up, tapping the
ball back into the basket as it fell.
Navy started off with a jump,
forcing Hopkins to assume the defensive. After a few minutes'
passwork, during which the Hopkins defense seemed impregnable,
Byerle at last broke through qnd
scored the first goal. Cuneo netted a foul, and then clever team
work on the part of Weiner and
Cuneo enabled the latter to score,
and Hopkins was ahead. Byerle
again turned the tables by netting
a long shot. The score see-sawed
back and forth, till just before the
whistle Navy took a spurt and the
half ended 15-11 in the favor of
the home team.
At the beginning of the second
period Weiner netted two goals in
rapid succession, tieing the count.
However, this seemed to be the
limit of the efforts of the Black
and Blue, for during the remainder of the contest only one more
basket was netted, while the future admirals piled up the score.

The Johns Hopkins University ,
announceS in the. division of the
College Courses for Teachers a
course on American :art to be
given by Professor David M. Robinson, February 12 to May 27,
1920. This will be a study, illustrated by slides and photographs,
of the different phases of the development of art in America, and
will deal especially with architecture, sculpture and painting from
Colonial times down to and including contemporary art movements.
OUTLINE OF LECTURES.
A ItellITFCTURE.
1. American Archaeology. Pre-colonial art in Peru, Yucatan, Mexico,
and among the cliff-dwellers. Colonial
, and Spanish architecture in America.
French, Spanish and Dutch influence
in America. Virginia and the South.
New England. Eighteenth century colonial architecture. Churches. Public
Buildings.
2. Classicism and the Greek revival.
Thomas Jefferson, the pioneer in the
Roman revival. Latrobe, the introducer of Greek forms. The later
classicists. Domestic architecture. The
Gothic revival. Eclecticism. The adoption of Romanesque and Renaissance
forms. Neoclassicism and other modern forms. The Woolwoyth Building.

Rah! for Mr. Kistler.

We do not believe that our undergraduate body quite realizes
just to what degree it is indebted
to Mr. Theodore Kistler for his labors, past and present, in our behalf. He has not only brought the
basketball team forth from its
semi-obscurity, but has filled a
long-felt need for something of a
social nature, not quite as elaborate as the cotillions and a little
more intimate than the pure-andsimple athletic contests. We are
offered each year, of course occasional Dramatic Club exhibitioiis, Glee Club concerts and varsity and inter-class debates, but
these do little more than begin to
fill the gap.
Our memories hearken back to
the old It 0. T. C. days of two
years ago, when Mr. Kistler performed for us a similar service in
organizing the popular series of
battalion hops. These were very
simply arranged, and were unanimously acclaimed successful in
every way. Last year we had our
S. A. T. C. hops and one or two
informal "Black and Blue" dances.
This year's social season will certainly surpass those which for several years have preceded it.
There but remains the mention
of a few of the ways in which we
may co-operate with Mr. Kistler,
Coach Murphy and the floor cornittee in bringing the basketball
dance series to its highest point of
success. Those who are not dancing should bear in mind the hints
of Mr. Murphy about smoking and
hats and blocking the floor. Those
whose tastes run to the more vibratory styles of dancing mightre-

term me the hydrogen in concentration ; beam-trawl hauls are taken
at the bottom in order to obtain

The purpose of this survey is,
first, to determine the normal biological and physical conditions
throughout the year so that when
great mortality of fishes, oysters,
clams, crabs, etc. occur, there will
be normal data at hand from
which to determine the abnormal
conditions that bring about the
trouble; second, to learn all that
is possible concerning the movements of layers of water of different density, different temperature and different plankton content (fish food value), in the hope
that the information may throw
light on the migration of fishes
and crabs into and in Chesapeake
Bay at certain times of the year;
third, to study especially the fauna of deep holes which occur in
many places; fourth, to study the
so-called "barren bottoms" at the
mouths of rivers; fifth, to obtain
information of value to geologists
concerning the deposition of calcium carbonate by a study of the
hydrogen ion concentration, and
sixth, to gather as much information as possible which will bear on
the conservation of the fisheries
resources of Chesapeake Bay.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

A glance at the notices on the official bulletin board will convince
one that there are at Johns Hopkins a small number of "witty"
students who indulge in the petty
practice of adding finishing
touches to the spelling of many
words on the notices. This "leadpencil vandalism" should not be
tolerated here, and I, as one who
fails to be tickled by such humor,
urge that sophomore paddles be
used unsparingly upon these delinquents, regardless of their class
or age. The golden rule or paddle
should not be spared to abolish
this primary school habit that a
few boys still possess. Yours for
SENIOR.

Sir—It seems to me that Hopkins is somewhat deficient in the
number of its student publications. Most colleges of this size
support at least two, and often
three, undergraduate periodicals.
Hopkins has but one—THE NEWS
LETTER.

Certainly there should be established here a student literary
magazine. The argument that a
publication of this sort would not
be supported by male students
has little force in view • of the
notable success of the Princeton,
Yale and many other college litmagazines.

erary

become far more abundant in

Well, examinations will soon be
here and I hope that everybody
is perfectly satisfied with their
exam schedule; I did the best I
• could to arrange it so that no one
took more than three exams a
day. If in any rare instance I
have fallen down on the job, I
most humbly beg forigiveness. You
see, old George doesn't forget his
friends in their time of trial, theoretically speaking.
That's one thing I admire in
Dr. Dansig, his liberal ideas. The
other morning I heard him say:
"Mr. Harden, I don't mind you
being absent, I never count absences but I can't stand dumbness.'
You ought to get on to this
stuff, Mr. Harden, for some day
you'll be a math teacher. I predict, sir that you will fail in business, and
' fail in engineering, and
fail in the practice of the law, and
then you will become a math
teacher." "Speaking from your
own experience, Doctor?" said Mr.
Harden, and right there the argument ended.
From all that I can gather, Senor Cabello's class in Spanish elements takes the cake, wins the
grand pittno and in general walks
off with all the prizes when it
comes to furnishing material for
my illustrious quack column.
About a quarter of an hour before
the end of the period, Elmer Jones
breezed into the room last Tuesday morning amid uproarious
cheers and bursting peals of laughter. "That's all right, Mr. Jones,"
said the Senor, "that's a lot better
than loafing down at the postofUe and you know the Bible
says'
that the last shall be first."
And then after things had quieted
down a bit, Mr. Cabello asked,
"What is the present of the verb
%ober'?" "Albeit; what is it?"
answered wee "Billie" Hoffman.
I leave it to you, gentlemen, if
that class isn't a pig's knuckle.
Am I right, or am I right?
From the far and distant region of the Medical School comes
the faintly revibrating echo of the
new motto that the faculty is
preaching this year: "Keep 'em
alive, boys; keep 'em alive—dead
men pay no bills."
And that reminds me of a story
I have had in the back of my head
for a good many months. Dr.
"Hygiene" Abercrombie was giving our little red-headed "Dick"
Tome- his physical examination.
He seemed fit as a fiddle in every
way except one. "Doc" Abercrombie diagnosed, "You're a little
stiff." Quickly the Irish blood
came to the fore as "Dick" shot
back: "And you're a big stiff."
I wish you all kinds of luck on
your exams, gentlemen. I know
you hate 'em, but just think how
hard they fall on us faculty and
be consoled.

LECTRICITY has leveled
E
1-4 the Continental Divide. The

steam locomotive, marvelous as it is
after a century of development, cannot meet all of the presentdemandsfor
transportation facilities. Its electric
rival has proved to be far superior.

Some Advantages of
Railroad Electrification

On the mountain divisions of the
Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul
Railway—the world's greatest electrification—giant electric locomotives
today lift an ever increasing freight
tonnage over the mile-high Rockies
and also make traveling clean and
comfortable. They utilize the abundant energy of distant waterfalls and
then, by returning some of this
power to the trolley, safely brake the
trains on descending grades. And
their capabilities are not impaired
by excessively cold weather when the
Steam engine is frozen and helpless.

Saving the Nation's coal
Lower maintenance costs.
Greater reliability and fewer
delays.
Ability to haul smoothly
heavier trains at higher
speed.
Operation of electric locomotives unaffected by extreme
cold.
Ability to brake trains on
descending grades by returning power to the trolley.

ii

Electricity is the power which
drives the trains of New York City's
subway and elevated systems. It
operates the locks and tows the ships
through the Panama Canal. It propels the Navy's latest super-dreadnaught, the New Mexico. Electric
mine locomotives have replaced the
slow-moving mule and the electric
automobile has also come to doan important service. Such achievements
were made possible by the extensive
research and manufacturing activities
of the General Electric Company.
Electricity has become the universal
motive power. It has contributed
efficiency and comfort to every form
of transportation service and in this
evolution General Electric apparatus
has played a large part — from
mighty electric locomotives to
the tiny lamp for the automobile.

The Jaraary meeting of the
Johns Hopkins Zionist Society
took place on January 28, the
speaker being Mr. Abraham Caplan of the Jewish Big Brother
League of this city. Mr. Caplan
presented a very.thoughtful paper,
entitled "The Zionist and Jewish
Social Problems," in which he asserted that the Zionist should attempt to understand intelligently
the problems confronting the Jews
living in the modern countries of
today. Mere philanthropy is not
sufficient; the remedy lies in the
resumption of the more vigirous
Jewishness that characterized the
life of Jews in previous years.
To quote the speaker:
"Zionists can ill-afford to be
thoughtless in the matter of social
service. They cannot regard Jewish social problems from a standpoint other than Zionistic. The
Zionist, essentially a realist, must
realize that these problems will be
solved by a general return to the
Jewish manner of life rather than
by the formulae of social workers.
"The student of Jewish history
finds little solace in the large institution of philanthropy. As a
Zionist I object to the process of
pauperization which has come as
a result of the free expansion of
the philanthropic idea. * * *
"What should be the attitude of
the thoughtful Zionist with reference to Jewish social problems?
It should be cautious, rational
and intelligent. It should be that
of one who knows that Jewish
problems have causes and that the
causes are deserving of intenser
consideration that the conditions
themselves."
The reading of the paper was
• followed by a discussion by Dr.
Blondheim.
An announcement was made regarding dues. All members of the
Society who have not already done
so may enroll as members of the
Zionist Organization of America
by remitting two dollars ($2.00)
to Mr. A. Fedder, the treasurer of
the Society.
Attention is again called to the
Study Circle in - General Zionism.
This circle, which has so far
Proved quite popular, will resume

If the present outlook may be
i.iken as a criterion, this should be
a banner lacrosse year for Hopkins from every standpoint. The
team N'ill undoubtedly live up to
the past Hopkins standard, as
nearly every member of last year's
team will be back and because
"Father Bill" Smeisser and
Rainey Wolfe will again be the
coaches.
The schedule is a hard one, for
the best lacrosse teams in the
rountry have been booked. In addition to the teams usually met,
the manager has gotten games
with Cornell, Harvard and Stevens, and is now negotiating with
Yale and Syracuse for matches.
Not only is the schedule a good
one, but it also has another great
advantage—probably every one of
the ten games except that with
Harvard will be played at home.
, In addition to the scheduled
games, if the Johns Hopkins team
wins the championship of the
Southern division of colleges, as
seems very probable, it will play
the champion of the Northern division early in June.

following day the first regular

Meyer. Since then practice has
been held every day the weather
has permitted, and every Wednesday and Saturday, rain or shine.
The coaches will be out on these
two (lays every week, and will give
blackboard talks if the weather is
too bad for practice.
Over sixty men have reported,
and about thirty more are expected after the examinations, when
practice will be begun in earnest.
Among these are the nine or ten
letter men and about as many
more from last year's Red Eagles.
It may well be seen that from
these and the new men who have
shown promise a team will be
picked which will uphold the Hopkins lacrosse reputation. The succes.s of lacrosse this year depends
on the team, the schedule and the
support. As the calibre of th_e
first two of these is assured, all
that is needed is the backing of
the student body.

A biological and hydrographic
survey of the waters of Chesapeake Bay is_being undertaken by
the Bureau of Fisheries under the
direction of Dr. R. P. Cowles, Associate Professor of Zoology in
Johns Hopkins University. In this
investigation all information possible is obtained concerning the
biological and physical conditions
that exist in Chesapeake Bay during spring, summer, fall and winter, and it is planned to continue
the work for several years. The
Fish Commission S. S. Fishhawk,
which is at the disposal of the
survey, makes six or seven cruises
at intervals during the year, and'
visits during each cruise some
thirty or forty stations distributed
in lines extending across the bay in
such a way as to cover all regions
of interest from Cape Charles and
Cape Henry to Swan Point and
North Point. At each station
quantitative samples of sea water
for salinity and plankton examination are taken at different
depths from the surface to the bottom, using the Green-Bigelow water bottle; horizontal and vertical
tow nets are employed to obtain
qualitative samples of the plankton, which are used to aid in the
study of the quantitative plankton
samples; accurate temperature
readings at the surface and at different depths are made by means
of reversing thermometers; the direction and velocity of the current
is determined at various depths by
means of the Eckman current

PROF. LOVEJOY ON TEACHING
Head of Department of Philosophy Addresses Freshmen on the Calling of
the University Teacher.

EIOR real enjoyment
and delight, one box
of Murads is worth a
dozen packages of
ordinary cigarettes that
"merely smoke.”

The first of a series of talks to
the freshman class on the vocations to which college students
look forward was given on Wednesday, January 2$, by Professor
Arthur 0. Lo.vejoy. As President
of the American Association of
University Professors, Dr. Lovejoy is eminently qualified to discuss the teaching profession. Of
the university teacher Ile said that
it should be clearly understood
that a man who is fitted to enter
this calling could earn more
money in another. If his future
happines depends upon his owning a motor car, and he cannot be
satisfied with the admirable contrivance of Mr. Henry Ford, he
should hesitate about becoming a
teacher. But there are other rewards for the teacher. • He has
what most men love, namely,
power. This is not power to boss
numbers of men or to direct human action, but power over civilization, influence upon the facts of
fundamental significance in the
life of man. From this point of
view the most powerful man of the
nineteenth century was Charles
Darwin.
Another intrinsic reward for
the university teacher is found in
life in a university community.
Next to the church, the university
is the most venerable and dignified
of associations, and most men
value the opportunity to do their
life's work under the conditions
which if offers.
A third recompense for the
scholar's labor is the fact that he
is in good company—the best of
the deads, in books, and successive generations of young men. By
these latter he is kept young and
made to look to the future rather
than to the past. His function as
a teacher enables him to influence
powerfully the leaders of the next
generation. Meanwhile he enjoys
the exercise of his own powers,
and if he has chosen wisely, is repaid by the fun of his job.

RESUME OF FOOTBALL SEASON

(Continuedfrom page I)
as possible, but the best they could
do against the first string, which
was put back in for the second
half, was to score 18 points. Hopkins made several good gains, getting three first downs in all; but
whenever the team was within
striking distance of the Navy goal
line a bad pass from the center
spoiled what looked several times
like a touchdown. Captain Jones
was injured in this game and did
not regain his old-time form until
the game with Western Maryland. Cashell was shifted back to
his old position at full for a part
of the game, and Cromwell was
given a chance to show what he
could do in center. His passing
was no better than that displayed
by Cashell a week before against
Mt. St. Mary's, and all loyal rooters were delighted to learn that
"Stem" Hecht, for two years AllMary land center, would return to
the iiversity.
A week of good hard practice
followed, and in the third game of
the season the fast Gallaudet
eleven was defeated, 33 to 9, Hopkins coming from behind in the
last quarter and scoring 27 points.
This game was very encouraging
to all Hopkins supporters, and it
was seen that the team was going
to have to be seriously considered
in the state championship race. A
real punch was uncovered in this
game, and the work of Cashell,
who returned to center, was all
that could be desired. In the
backfield the work of Hoffman was
especially good, while Tome, Bardiet and Watson left nothing to be
desired. Jones played a beautiful
game until he was knocked out in
the second quarter. The team had
now begun to show what it was
really capable of, and visions of
the state championship began to
appear in the distance.
The next week the team journeyed to Swarthmore, where it
met defeat at the hands of the fast
eleven representing that institution by a 20-to-6 score. The game
was played under the worst possible circumstances for the Hopkins eleven. The field was very
heavy and the backs were unable
to get foothold enough to start,
many plays hardly reaching the
line of scrimmage before they were
stopped by the Swarthmore men,
who were evidently used to playing on a field covered with three
inches of mud. Hecht played most
of the game at center, Cashell going back to his old position in the
backfield. Hampered and seemingly rather discouraged by the
mud, Hopkins failed to show
either the team-work or the driVe
that had characterized the play
against Gallaudet the week previous. Swarthmore had a fast,
heavy team, and every play was
covered in perfect interference.
• Hopkins' one score came after a

pretty run of 65 yards by Barchet,
who had intercepted a forward
pass.
Several changes were made for
the next gaine—that with Lebanon
Valley. Cashel' was again shifted
to center, and Calkins, who had
been end and general utility man,
was shifted to fullback. Hopkins
again showed a driving attack,
with Calkins as the chief ground
gainer. The game ended with
Hopkins a 20-to-6 victor. The work
of the line was especially good in
this game, the plunging attack of
Lebanon Valley being stopped by
the excellent work of Ed Wood,
Landy and Egerton. Particularly
pleasing to Hopkins was the unexpected ability displayed by Calkins, playing his first game in the
backfield.
Hopkins seemed rather overconfident, and the next week was defeated, 7 to 0, by Haverford in a
close and exciting game. Hopkins
should have been victor with comparative ease, but poor judgment
on the part of the quarterback and
the inexperience of Calkins, who
was stuck in long enough to permit Haverford to put a forward
pass over his head, proved a big
enough handicap to defeat the
Black and Blue. Hopkins showed
a powerful attack, but were unable to sustain it inside the 20yard line. Calkins was again the
best bet in the Hopkins attack,
and Landy did excellent work in
the line.
After d week of unusually hard
practice Western Maryland was
met in the first of the three state
games. The visitors were light and
absolutely unable to stop Hopkins' hard-charging backs. Captain
Jones showed a welcome return to
form in this game, running 70
yards for a touchdown on a play
inside tackle. The whole Hopkins
team performed creditably, both
the offense and the defense doing
their full share, the final count
being 30 to 6. Western Maryland
managed to get one touchdown on
a beautiful forward pass to their
veteran captain, Langrall. The
game was won without opening up
any of the new plays being saved
for the games with St. Johns and
State.
The next team on the schedule
was St. John's, and in this game
Hopkins seemed to be suffering a
bit from overconfidence, being
forced to the limit to hold the Soldiers to a 13-to-13 tie. Any one
who saw the games with Western
Maryland and State knows how
much Hopkins was off.form on
that day. Calkins and Jones
starred on the offense and on the
defense the tackling of Jones was
of the highest order. "Bill" Wood

in the game, and his loss was badly felt, St. John's making many
gains on end runs that Wood probably would have stopped.
In the last game of the season,
on Thanksgiving Day, the muchheralded team from Maryland

best backs in the state, were the
particularly bright stars from the

Organized Measures Taken to Guard
Against Fire and Accident—Committees Appointed By President Goodnow.

President Frank J. Goodnow
has inaugurated a movement to
insure the maintenance and preservation of the splendid buildings
on the Homewood site by means of
building inspection committees, to
consist of the following members:
Gilman Hall—Dr. R. V. D. Magoffin, Chairman; George Wagner,
Paul Hinrichs, Charles T. Leber,
George Deickman and Millard
Foard.
Mechanical
and
Electrical
Building—J. C. Smallwood, Chairman; Edel, H. H. Holland, Wessels and Salter.
Civil Engineering tuilding—W.
E. Dehoff, Chairman; Phillipy,
Herring, Zeskind and T. T. Hubbard.
Each committee has been instructed to make monthly inspections of their building and to report to President Goodnow regarding conditions found, particularly in regard to (a) fire risks,
(b) protection of equipment and
(c) careless practices.
Such efficient and reliable inspection will have a great influence on the morale of the University and also on the economic life
of the city, for it is hoped that the
student body will carry the same
ideas of safety into their later vocations. Further details regarding the movement will be given in
a later issue.
